title: 108_s2511
content: The Act may be cited as the "Chimayo Water Supply System and Espanola Filtration Facility Act of 2004". It includes definitions for the Chimayo Water Supply System. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct a feasibility study for a water supply system in the Santa Cruz River Valley for the town of Chimayo, New Mexico. The study will determine the construction of potable water transmission lines, pump stations, and storage reservoirs. The feasibility study for a water supply system in the Santa Cruz River Valley for the town of Chimayo, New Mexico will include considerations for operating the system with the Espanola Water Filtration Facility, various water supply options, reuse of water sources, alternative water supplies, and total lifecycle costs. The study for a water supply system in the Santa Cruz River Valley for Chimayo, New Mexico will explore alternative water sources like surface water, brackish water, and deep aquifer groundwater. It will also assess the total lifecycle costs, including operation, maintenance, and management costs. The Secretary must complete the study within 3 years, with a 75 percent Federal cost share, and coordinate with relevant agencies for access to land. The Secretary will coordinate with relevant agencies for access to land and drilling exploratory wells on Bureau of Land Management land for a feasibility study on water resources for the Town. A report on the study results must be submitted to Congress within 1 year of completion or 4 years after enactment of the Act. The Secretary may provide emergency water supply development assistance to eligible individuals or entities in the study area, including activities such as hauling water, installing water purification technology, drilling wells, and installing pump stations and pipelines for residential water connections. The Secretary may provide emergency water supply development assistance for community wells, drilling wells, pump stations, storage reservoirs, transmission pipelines, distribution pipelines, and emergency water supply systems. The Federal share of the cost for these activities is 75 percent. SEC. 104 authorizes appropriations for sections 102 and 103 for fiscal years 2005-2008 and 2005-2010 respectively. Funds under subsection (a)(1) cannot be used for water infrastructure construction. The term "component" refers to water delivery infrastructure developments, while "facility" pertains to the Espanola water filtration facility. The Secretary of the Interior, through the Commissioner of Reclamation, is defined as the "Secretary." The Secretary is tasked with providing financial assistance to Espanola, New Mexico, for the construction of a water filtration facility to meet future water demands in the region. This includes the construction of presedimentation basins and an influent pump station. The Secretary may provide financial assistance for the construction of water infrastructure in Espanola, New Mexico, including presedimentation basins, influent pump station, pretreatment facility, filtration facilities, water storage, booster pump station, sludge dewatering facilities, and water transmission lines. Reclaimed water will be used to enhance groundwater and surface water supplies. The Secretary may provide financial assistance for the study, planning, design, and construction of a water delivery infrastructure development for the Santa Clara and San Juan Pueblos of New Mexico. The Federal share of the total cost shall not exceed 25 percent, and funds provided may not be used for operation or maintenance of the facility. Authorization of $3,000,000 for facility construction from 2005 to 2009.
